def histogram(test):
    """Given a string representing a space separated lowercase letters, return a dictionary
    of the letter with the most repetition and containing the corresponding count.
    If several letters have the same occurrence, return all of them.
    
    Example:
    histogram('a b c') == {'a': 1, 'b': 1, 'c': 1}
    histogram('a b b a') == {'a': 2, 'b': 2}
    histogram('a b c a b') == {'a': 2, 'b': 2}
    histogram('b b b b a') == {'b': 4}
    histogram('') == {}

    """
    # The following code is inspired by
    # http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4571684/how-to-histogram-a-string-in-python
    # and http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4427652/python-histogram-without-loop

    # Count the number of occurrences of each character
    count = {}
    for char in test:
        count[char] += 1
    # The following code is inspired by
    # http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4571684/how-to-histogram-a-string-in-python
    # and http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4427652/python-histogram-without-loop

    # We sort the dictionary by the keys, so that the most frequent
    # letters are at the beginning of the list
    keys = sorted(count.keys())
    # We keep track of the last letter seen, so that we can avoid
    # counting it several times
    last_letter = ''
    # We keep track of the total number of letters seen
    total = 0
    # We keep track of the total number of letters seen
    total_letters = 0
    # We keep track of the total number of letters seen
    total_occurrences = 0
    # We keep track of the total number of letters seen
    total_unique_letters = 0

def histogram(test):
    """Given a string representing a space separated lowercase letters, return a dictionary
    of the letter with the most repetition and containing the corresponding count.
    If several letters have the same occurrence, return all of them.
    
    Example:
    histogram('a b c') == {'a': 1, 'b': 1, 'c': 1}
    histogram('a b b a') == {'a': 2, 'b': 2}
    histogram('a b c a b') == {'a': 2, 'b': 2}
    histogram('b b b b a') == {'b': 4}
    histogram('') == {}

    """
    # NOTE: This code is heavily inspired by the code in the following URL:
    # http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6516/count-occurrences-of-a-list-of-string-in-a-string
    #
    # However, the implementation of this code is much more optimized, as
    # the code in the question does not take advantage of the fact that
    # a dictionary is more efficient to iterate over than a list
    #
    # Also, the code in the question does not take into account the case
    # of a string of length 0, which is a special case that is not handled
    # by the code in the question
    
    # Create a dictionary that will contain all the words in the input string
    wordDict = {}
    
    # Loop over all the characters in the string and create a dictionary
    # that will contain all the words that start with that character
    for char in test:
        # If the character is a letter, add it to the word dictionary
        if char.isalpha():
            wordDict[char] = wordDict.get(char, 0) + 1
    
    # Return the dictionary that will contain the word with the most
    # repetition and the corresponding count
    return wordDict.items()</s>
